title: Problem Overview
content: Erdos Problem #686: Can every N >= 2 be written as prod(m+i)/prod(n+i) for k >= 2 and m >= n+k? Status: OPEN.
mathContext: From [Er79d]. Asks about representation of integers as ratios of consecutive products. Related to Problem 677.

title: Consecutive Product
content: consecutiveProduct(n, k) := prod_{i=1}^k (n+i). Equals (n+k)!/n! = k! * C(n+k, k).
mathContext: Product of k consecutive integers starting at n+1. Fundamental building block.

title: Ratio Expression
content: ratioExpression(n, m, k) := consecutiveProduct(m,k) / consecutiveProduct(n,k) as rational.
mathContext: The ratio is taken over Q to handle exact division. Equals C(m+k,k)/C(n+k,k).

title: Representability
content: IsRepresentable(N, n, m, k) := k >= 2 and m >= n+k and ratioExpression(n,m,k) = N. Representable(N) := exists such triple.
mathContext: The central definition. Constraints ensure meaningful ratio > 1.

title: Main Conjecture
mathContext: Claims every integer >= 2 can be expressed as a ratio of consecutive products.

title: Constraint Analysis
content: numerator_gt_denominator: m >= n+k implies larger product. ratio_gt_one: ratio exceeds 1.
mathContext: k >= 2 excludes trivial single-factor ratios. m >= n+k ensures no overlap and ratio > 1.

title: Small Cases
content: N = 6 works: (3)(4)/(1)(2) = 6. N = 2 is harder to find. Examples show non-triviality.
mathContext: Finding the right triple (n, m, k) for each N requires search. Some cases are harder than others.

title: Binomial Connection
mathContext: Connects consecutive products to binomial coefficients. Ratio becomes C(m+k,k)/C(n+k,k).

title: Follow-Up Question
content: RepresentableSet(n, k) := {N | exists m >= n+k, ratio = N}. This set is infinite (ratio_mono, representable_set_infinite).
mathContext: For fixed n, k, as m increases, ratios increase. What integers appear?

title: Divisibility Structure
content: For ratio to be integer, subtle divisibility needed. Products have complex prime factorization.
mathContext: The difficulty: ensuring denominator divides numerator exactly for each target N.

title: Problem Status
content: The problem is OPEN. Unknown whether all N >= 2 are representable. erdos_686_statement gives formal statement.
mathContext: Combines number theory (factorials, binomials) with representation theory.
